The mass balance is 98–100%. c TON: total turnover number, moles of products formed per mole of catalyst. d TOF: turnover frequency which is calculated by the expression TON/ reaction time (h−1). Biochar as supporting material for heterogeneous Mn(II) catalysts: Efficient olefins epoxidation with H2O2 Leticia Pierri a b Aikaterini Gemenetzi a Alexandra Mavrogiorgou a Jussara Borges Regitano b Yiannis Deligiannakis c d Maria Louloudi a d * a Department of Chemistry, University of Ioannina, 45110 Ioannina, Greece Department of Chemistry University of Ioannina Ioannina 45110 Greece b Department of Soil Science, University of São Paulo, Luiz de Queiroz College of Agriculture (USP/ESALQ), Piracicaba, SP, Brazil Department of Soil Science University of São Paulo Luiz de Queiroz College of Agriculture (USP/ESALQ) Piracicaba SP Brazil c Department of Physics, University of Ioannina, 45110 Ioannina, Greece Department of Physics University of Ioannina Ioannina 45110 Greece d Institute of Materials Science and Computing, University Research Center of Ioannina, 45110 Ioannina, Greece Institute of Materials Science and Computing University Research Center of Ioannina Ioannina 45110 Greece ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A novel type of hybrid catalytic materials [MnII-L@BC] has been developed using biochar (BC) as support material for covalent grafting of a MnII Schiff-base catalyst (MnII-L). The hybrid [MnII-L@BC] materials have been evaluated for an important catalytic process, epoxidation of olefins using H2O2 as oxidant. A number of different substrates were used, with cyclohexene achieving the highest yields. When compared to the non-grafted, homogeneous MnII-L, the hybrid catalysts [MnII-L@BC] show a significant enhancement of the catalytic efficiency i.e. as documented by the increase of Turnover Numbers (TONs) (826 for [MnII -L-SS550ox ] and 822 for [MnII -L-SW550ox ]) and Turnover Frequencies (TOFs) (551 h−1 for [MnII -L-SS550ox ] and 411 h−1 for [MnII -L-SW550ox ]). The interfacial catalytic mechanism and the role of the BC support have been analyzed by Raman and Electron Paramagnetic Resonance spectroscopies. Based on these data we discuss a mechanism where the high efficiency of the hybrid materials involves the biochar carbon layers acting as promoters of the substrate and products kinetics. To a broader context, this work exemplifies that biochar-based hybrid materials are potent for oxidative catalysis technologies. Keywords Biochar Epoxidation catalysis Schiff base Raman EPR Introduction Epoxides are among the most valuable and versatile building blocks in industrial organic synthesis [1] e.g. for production of resins, varnishes, adhesives, etc. In principle, epoxides can be obtained through selective oxidative catalysis of olefins, using metal Schiff-base complexes as catalysts, in both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalytic systems [2,3]. Among various oxidative transition-metal catalysts, MnII is advantageous due to its economic viability and efficiency [4]. In addition, certain Mn catalysts resist oxidative deactivation and this is an accountable advantage in catalytic applications. Furthermore, to increase the stability against oxidative self-destruction, the catalyst’s immobilization on a suitable solid support has been proposed [5], facilitating its separation and recycling, diminishing potential effluent contamination, and optimizing the process [4,6]. Desirable properties of a catalyst’s solid support are stability under prolonged use, chemical inertness, reusability, tunable specific surface area and porosity, and appropriate chemical structure [7,8]. Although inorganic materials e.g. like silica, are robust as a catalyst support [2], carbonaceous materials present other advantages such as resistance to both acidic and basic media, ability to adapt their chemical properties in order to control polarity and hydrophobicity, stability at high temperatures, presence of oxygen surface groups, and lower costs [4,9]. Carbonaceous supports seem to generate kinetically faster grafted epoxidation catalysts than the homologous on silica-based supports, resulting in higher turnover frequency (TOF) numbers, as demonstrated by our group [4–7,9]. This has been verified for carbons originating from pyrolytic carbon from recycled tyres [4] or commercial activated carbon [7,9]. One possible explanation for this behavior is the hydrophobic feature of carbon matrix, which might accelerate the olefin approach towards the active metal complex while repelling at the same time the water generated during the catalytic reaction [9,10]. From the practical point of view, the aforementioned works demonstrate that grafting of a molecular catalyst on a C-matrix can accelerate significantly catalytic TOFs i.e. up to 10-fold compared for the same catalyst grafted on a SiO2 support [6,11]. For example, we have found that homogeneous Mn or Fe catalysts grafted on carbonaceous matrices accomplish a pilot catalytic epoxidation reaction within 1−5 h which is 4–5 times faster vs. 18−24 h needed for the same catalysts grafted on silica-based supports [6,11]. Biochar is the pyrogenic carbonaceous material originating from thermal decomposition of organic materials under oxygen-lean pyrolysis [12], being the by-product of bio-oil and/or biogas generation. During the recent years, biochar is considered in a sustainability context, since it is not only the waste from biofuel production, but is also claimed as soil amendment due to its proved capacity to enhance soil quality, to remediate inorganic and organic pollutants, to mitigate greenhouse gases, and to promote carbon sequestration [13–18]. Therefore, biochar application as support material for catalysis technologies is more environmentally friendly than other synthetic carbon sources, like activated carbon [7,9] e.g., in addition to its lower price and better suitability. Herein we present the development of hybrid catalytic materials [MnII-L@BC] synthesized by covalent grafting of a well-characterized molecular Mn Schiff-base catalyst, MnII-L, on biochar carbon particles, BC (Fig. 1 ). Thus, two different biochars, differing in their origin i.e. sugarcane straw and sawdust, have been used as support materials in order to verify our finding that the carbonaceous matrices in general, even those derived from agro-wastes, offer a significant advantage in supported catalysts for epoxidation reactions with H2O2 such as high rapidity. The specific aims of the present work were [i] to develop novel hybrid catalytic materials [MnII-L@BC] using low-cost biochar from agro-residues as supporting material, [ii] to evaluate its performance for epoxidation catalytic process, and [iii] to discuss the physicochemical mechanism underlying its superior kinetic performance when compared to the homologous SiO2-based catalysts. Materials and methods Chemicals and biochar synthesis All the chemicals were of analytical grade, purchased from Aldrich in their highest commercial purity. Two biochars were used as pristine materials, both pyrolyzed at 550 °C but differing in terms of feedstock (sugarcane straw and sawdust). The detailed characterization of the biochars can be found in the work of Conz et al. [14]. The biochars were produced by slow pyrolysis in a hermetically sealed reactor. Briefly, after drying the raw materials at 105 °C, the reactor was saturated with N2 and the temperature was increased at a rate of 10 °C min−1 for the first 30 min. Then, the rate was raised to 20 °C min−1 until it reached the desired temperature (550 °C) and the materials were kept for 15 min until the reaction completion. The material inside the reactor, however, was only removed after 12 h [14]. Finally, the biochars were sieved through a 2 mm mesh and characterized for their acidity, total carbon and ash contents. The mentioned properties of the final materials (herein called as SS550 and SW550, for sugarcane straw and sawdust, respectively) were: SS550: pH: 9.1; total C: 68 %; ash content: 17 %; and SW550: pH: 7.4; total C: 80 %; ash content: 1 %. Catalysts synthesis and characterization The SS550 and SW550 biochars were activated by HNO3 oxidation, to promote the formation of surficial carboxylate functionalities for the catalyst anchoring [7]. 5 g of each biochar was stirred with 90 mL of HNO3 65 % for 6 h in a reflux system at 100 °C. The materials were then washed several times with deionized water to reach pH values close to neutrality, dried at 60 °C for 24 h and the materials recovered were named SS550ox and SW550ox . In this step, we have verified by EPR spectroscopy that strong acid removed any Fe and Mn present in the pristine biochar. In parallel, a Schiff-base ligand previously developed by our group [19], was prepared by a stepwise condensation of one equivalent of triethylenetetramine with two equivalents of acetylacetone and one equivalent of 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde (1:2:1 molar ratio). Subsequently, 1.2 μmol of the aforementioned ligand (herein called L) was stirred with 1 μmol of (3-chloropropyl)-trimethoxysilane with MeOH, in reflux at 60 °C for 48 h. Then, 1.2 μmol of MnII salt (MnCl2∙4H2O) dissolved in 10 mL of MeOH were added, keeping the mixture in room temperature under magnetic stirring for 24 h. The resulting precursor, [MnII -L-silane], was anchored onto SS550ox and SW550ox , individually, by hydrolysis and co-condensation with the carboxylates groups of each oxidized biochar. For this, 500 mg of SS550ox or SW550ox were added into the solution of [MnII -L-silane] and the slurry was kept in a reflux system at 60 °C for 24 h. Finally, the solids were filtrated, washed several times with MeOH and EtOH, and dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h. The heterogeneous catalysts recovered were named MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox . For comparison, reference materials were produced, skipping the MnII addition step. So, the [ligand-silane] adduct was directly anchored onto the oxidized biochars, giving rise to the non-metalated L-SS550ox and L-SW550ox materials. All the materials (pristine, precursors and catalysts) were fully characterized by Powder X-Ray Diffractometry (XRD), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) porosimetry, Raman Spectroscopy, Electron Paramagnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (EPR), Thermogravimetric Analysis (TG/DTA) and Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR). The following conditions and equipment were used: XRD: diffractometer D8 Advance (Bruker), using CuKα (36Kv, 36 mA) radiation and a secondary beam graphite monochromator, with patterns recorded in the 2-theta 2(θ) range from 2 to 80° in steps of 0.03° and counting time of 2 s per step. Raman: Raman spectroscopy was performed with a HORIBA Xplora Plus Raman coupled to an Olympus BX41 microscope, equipped with a 785 nm diode laser as excitation source focused with the microscope. The powder samples were placed on a glass plate. The laser intensity was reduced to 1.5 mW, in order to avoid damage of the sample due to sample heating. The spectra were recorded for 3 s with 10 accumulations to obtain sufficient signal-to-noise ratio. EPR: A continuous-wave Brucker ER200D, equipped with an Agilent 5310A frequency counter was used. The spectrometer was running under a homemade software based on LabView. EPR spectra of the pristine biochars were obtained with the following conditions: Modulation Amplitude 4 Gptp; Modulation Frequency 100 kHz; Scans Accumulation 3; Microwave Power 1.26 mW; EPR spectra of the as-prepared catalysts were obtained with the following conditions: Solvent ethanol/acetone mixture 8/9 v/v; Modulation Amplitude 10 Gptp, Modulation Frequency 100 kHz; Scans Accumulation 1; Microwave Power 20 mW; EPR spectra of the recycled catalysts were obtained with the following conditions: Modulation Amplitude 10 Gptp, Modulation Frequency 100 kHz; Scans Accumulation 3; Microwave Power 20 mW. TG/DTA: Shimadzu DTG-60 analyzer, using a heat rate of 10 °C min−1 and a flow rate of synthetic air as a carrier gas of 50 cm3 min−1. FTIR: Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS5 spectrophotometer with transmission module iD1. The materials were analyzed after pellets preparation with KBr in a PerkinElmer manual hydraulic press at 6 tons for 3 min. BET: The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured at 77 K on a NOVAtouch LX2 Quantachrome porosimeter. Specific surfaces areas were determined with the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method using adsorption data points. Catalytic process The experiments were conducted in vials and followed a molar ratio of 1:2000:1000:1000 μmol (catalyst:oxidant:substrate:additive), using a mixture of acetone/MeOH (450 μL/400 μL) as the solvent system and with the addition of an internal standard (acetophenone/bromobenzene, 1000 μmol). The sequence of reactants were: i) acetone/MeOH; ii) H2O2 (30 %, v/v), added by a digitally controlled syringe pump (SP101IZ WPI) in a rate of 13,3 μL min−1; iii) substrate; iv) CH3COONH4, used as an additive; and v) catalyst (7.3 mg for MnII -L-SS550ox and 4.3 mg for MnII -L-SW550ox , based on the metal-complex loadings previously calculated by TG/DTA). Ammonium acetate was chosen as an additive because of its proton acceptor/donor behavior, acting as co-catalyst, and promoting higher Mn oxidation states [7]. Blank experiments showed that in the absence of catalyst or co-catalyst or the presence of just the biochars, the epoxidation reactions do not take place (in any case, the observed yields were lower than 1%). Cyclohexene, cyclopentene, cyclooctene, α-pinene, limonene, styrene, cis-stilbene, trans-β-methylstyrene and 1-hexene were studied as substrates. For each olefin, the catalytic reaction was prepared and studied by quantifying the yield of products. Each vial’s content was centrifuged and 0.2 μL of the supernatant was injected in a gas chromatographer coupled to a mass spectrometer (GC–MS, Shimadzu QP2010 SE). The integrals of the retention peaks were compared with the internal standard’s one to obtain the substrate conversion and the yield of the oxidation products. When alcohol (from limonene and cyclohexene oxidation) and ketone (from cyclohexene oxidation) were detected, as allylic oxidation products, Shul’pin’s procedure [20] was run to be sure that these products were not resulting from former hydroperoxides formation. The turnover numbers (TON) were calculated by the ratio between the moles of product formed and the moles of catalyst added. The catalytic kinetics was evaluated by the same reaction aforementioned, using cyclohexene as a substrate. Samples were taken at times T0, T30, T60, T120, T180, T240, T300, T420 and T1440 (minutes), analyzed by GC–MS and the redox potential (Eh) was followed by a Metrohm platinum electrode (type 6.0401.100) versus standard hydrogen electrode (SHE), previously calibrated with a Ferri/Ferro solution. The turnover frequencies (TOF) were calculated by the ratio between TONs and the equilibrium time needed to stabilize the olefin conversion. In order to confirm the equilibrium time for each catalyst, cyclooctene was used as substrate as well and the reaction progression was followed in each 30 min until 4 and 2.5 h for MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox , respectively. The reusability of heterogeneous catalysts is one of the main points to be evaluated concerning catalysts’ behavior. For this purpose, the recyclability of MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox were evaluated after obtaining the equilibrium time by the kinetic test mentioned before. The catalysts were used in a first catalytic run for 1.5 and 2 h, respectively, for MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox . In sequence, the solid was separated by centrifugation and washed three times with MeOH. After drying, the same amount of catalyst (7.3 mg for L-MnII-SS550ox and 4.3 mg for L-MnII-SW550ox ) was weighted and used in a new catalytic run, using the same catalytic conditions described. This procedure was repeated as many times as epoxide yields were produced. To better understand the data from recyclability experiments, EPR spectra were recorded for both the recovered catalytic materials and the filtrates, after the second and third use of the catalysts MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox , respectively. Results and discussion Material characterization XRD XRD diffractograms of pristine biochars as well as their functionalized correspondents showed the presence of amorphous C (sp3 ), according to the broad peak centered between 22° and 24° 2θ, (plane (002)) (Fig. 2 , black lines). The less intense peaks at 28.4° 2θ and 29.5° 2θ for the biochar SS550 and SW550 respectively, can be related to graphitic C (sp2 ), since the plane (002) refers to the stacking of layers of aromatic structures [21]. After oxidation with HNO3, though, these and the peaks of metal oxides disappeared (Fig. 2, red lines). That is, reflections at 40.5° and 50.3° 2θ for the planes (113) and (024) of Fe2O3 detected in the pristine materials were absent after oxidation, which means that both biochars had their ash impurities removed. This was also confirmed by EPR spectroscopy (not shown) since the originally Fe and Cu present in both pristine biochars were removed after the strong acid treatment. Thus, according to the XRD data, ongoing from the pristine materials (SS550/SW550) towards the final hybrids (MnII -L-SS550ox / MnII -L-SW550ox ) the synthetic protocol leads to a metal-free carbon matrix bearing the grafted catalyst. Raman Spectroscopy The spectra of pyrolytic biochars typically exhibit a complex pattern of intense peaks covering the region 1600 cm−1 to 1250 cm−1 [15]. Biochars produced at low pyrolysis temperatures <700 °C do not show only the “classical” 1580 cm−1 and 1350 cm−1 Raman peaks, which are indicative of the “graphitized” sp2- and sp3-hybridized graphitic C-atoms, respectively [22,23]. A careful Raman study of Li et al [15] demonstrated that in biochars pyrolyzed at low temperature, <600 °C, the Raman spectrum contains distinct molecular signatures of [i] small aromatic structures, up to 6–8 rings at 1450-1550cm−1 and [ii] sp3-rich alkyl-type chains at 1240−1350 cm−1. These peaks can be observed on the Raman spectra of both pristine materials and even more clearly on the Raman spectra of their functionalized counterparts (see Fig. 3 panel A for SS550 and panel B for SW550). S-band sp3-type carbons The Raman spectra for the two pristine materials SS550 and SW550 (black lines in Fig. 3A & B), respectively show the presence of considerable amounts of alkyl-based or carboxyl-based sp3 units i.e. marked as S-band at 1140−1280 cm−1 according to Li et al. [15]. After oxidation of the materials by HNO3 (red lines in Fig. 3A & B), the band at 1140cm−1 is enhanced in SS550ox while in SW550ox the change is minor. Oxidation of the materials is inducing the generation of additional carboxyl units in SS550ox . The SW550ox appears to undergo a less severe effect by the oxidation i.e. since the pristine SW550 contained significant amounts of carboxyl-sp3 units. D, G Band sp2/sp3 carbons The band at 1580 cm−1 is assigned to the E2g tangential mode (G band), while the band at 1350 cm−1 (D band) originates from sp3-type defects in graphitized units [22]. While in graphite-type materials these two bands signify the formation of extended graphitized layers [22,23], in biochar these bands should be considered as markers of regions where multi-ring fusion occurs, while the features between the D and G bands signify regions with few C-rings fused i.e. 6–8 rings [23]. In biochars, the region between the D–G bands is not flat but contains peaks, more prominent in SS550, which corresponds to these 6–8 ring formations. Notice that after oxidation the D–G region undergoes only minor changes, the most prominent is being the loss of the discrete features at 1400−1550 cm−1 in SS550ox . Noticeably, after the oxidative treatment, the SS550ox and SW550ox materials seem more comparable in terms of sp2/ sp3 units’ composition. Effect of MnII-L Functionalization The treatment for the covalent attachment of the MnII-L catalyst has a distinct effect on the sp2 and sp3 units’ profile. The MnII -L-SS550ox appears to have sharper Raman D and G bands (blue line in Fig. 3A), while the spectral band at 1240 cm−1 is diminished, as well as the 1400−1550 cm−1 features. In MnII -L-SW550ox , the changes are less pronounced. There is a loss of sp3-carbons signal at 1200 cm−1 and a less pronounced lowering of the small, graphitized rings in the 1400−1550 cm−1 region. Overall, the Raman analysis reveals that each biochar has a distinct dynamics and reactivity towards oxidation and surface grafting. SW550 biochar seems to be less prone to chemical modifications, while SS550 is more sensitive. The functional groups of the 1200−1240 cm−1 region are preferably the area where the MnII-L centers are grafted i.e. resulting in the loss of the sp3-signals. Electron Paramagnetic Resonance Spectroscopy The EPR spectra of the MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . As shown in the insets in both Fig. 4A and B, the pristine materials exhibit a carbon-based radical, typical of carbon materials [24]. The EPR spectra of the catalysts, MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox , both show a signal typical of monomeric MnII ions when coordinated with the ligand L [25] confirming that the MnII-L complex was successfully immobilized on the carbon matrix. It is underlined that the carbon matrices in MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox show no signals from adventitious Fe-oxides or other metal, which were present in the pristine biochar. As shown by the XRD data also, the HNO3 treatment step cleans up the biochar from the adventitious metals. Thus, the only metal centers present in MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox hybrids are the catalytic MnII-L complexes. The strong C-based radical EPR single in MnII -L-SS550ox originates form defects on the graphitized regions of the material. TGA & FTIR : The formation of surface oxygen groups after oxidation with HNO3 for the SS550ox and SW550ox can be assessed by TG/DTA and FT-IR (Figs. 5 and 6 ). The mass loss between 180 and 400 °C determined by thermogravimetry, e.g. the thermal decomposition of carboxylic groups (molar weight=45 g mol−1), was used to calculate the loading of oxygenated surface groups. We obtained 17.3 and 22.7% of weight loss for SS550ox and SW550ox , which resulted in ca. 2.5 mmol g−1 and 5 mmol g−1 of these groups formation, respectively (Fig. 5). Comparing Fig. 5B and D, it is evident that SW550 contains more exposed low-molecular-weight components, namely alkyl chains and not an extended graphitized lattice, giving rise to exothermic processes at lower temperatures than for SS550. In parallel, FT-IR analysis showed that the bands for the ν(CO) and (OCO) vibrations from 1709 to 1716 cm−1 and from 764 to 790 cm-1 respectively [26] were present in pristine SW550 and much less in SS550. These bands assigned to carboxyl-groups are increased after the acid-oxidation treatment in both materials. This FTIR-based information is in agreement with our Raman data, in Fig. 3A, B where the S-band at 1200−1240 cm−1 is increased upon oxidation. The following-upon grafting of the ligand results in a significant loss of the FTIR ν(CO) band from 1709 to 1716 cm−1 in the L-SS550ox material, while this band appears less modified in the L-SW550ox material. Thus, both FTIR and Raman indicate that during the surface-grafting process, the carboxylates are strongly modified due to their engagement in the linkage with the L moiety during functionalization. In parallel, the Raman data show that part of the carboxyl units in MnII -L-SS550ox material is depleted, possibly due to their loose association with the matrix. Thus, the MnII -L-SS550ox contains less sp3 carboxylic carbons i.e. 2.5 mmol g−1 of carboxylates in MnII -L-SS550ox vs. 5 mmol g−1 in MnII -L-SW550ox. Importantly, the fewer carboxylates available in MnII -L-SS550ox vs. MnII -L-SW550ox correlates with the significantly lower MnII-L-catalyst loading of 0.14 mmol g−1 in MnII -L-SS550ox vs. 0.21 mmol g−1 in MnII -L-SW550ox . In a more detailed analysis, the steps of loading of the catalyst complex onto the oxidized supports were monitored for both the non-metalated hybrid material and the final heterogeneous catalysts features. The stretching vibration of the Schiff-ligand imine group (ν(C꞊N) from 1612 to 1582 cm−1) [2] demonstrates that the L-silane precursor was attached to the supports in both L-SS550ox/ SW550ox and MnII -L-SS550ox/ SW550ox . In addition, the down-shift of ν(C꞊N) from 1600 to 1595 cm−1 from L-SS550ox to MnII -L-SS550ox and from 1602 to 1592 cm−1 from L-SW550ox to MnII -L-SW550ox indicates that the nitrogen atoms are involved in coordination to the manganese center [27]. By the TG/DTA spectra, a 7.0 and 10.6 % of weight loss was quantified, attributed to the metal complex anchoring on the biochars, resulting in loadings of 0.14 and 0.21 mmol∙g−1 for MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox , respectively (Fig. 5). BET : Both the pristine materials’ and the corresponding catalysts’ SSA values were determined by N2 adsorption at 77 K and calculated using the classical BET treatment (SBET) in the range (P/Po) = 0.05–0.30 [28]. MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox exhibit both a Type II adsorption isotherm. The catalysts’ SSA values are 3.9 ± 1.0 m2 g−1 for MnII -L-SS550ox and 8.0 ± 1.0 m2 g−1 for MnII -L-SW550ox . The analysis of the pore sizes shows that the surface-functionalized materials do not possess a porous structure. Thus, the MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox materials pose a compacted structure with negligible internal pores. All the measured specific-surface area values measured can be attributed only to the external surface of the carbon particles. Catalysis: alkene epoxidation Catalytic olefin epoxidation yields ranged from 18.9 to 63.7 % for MnII -L-SS550ox and from 8.9 to 53.5 % for MnII -L-SW550ox (Table 1 ). The lower epoxidation rates were obtained for cis-stilbene and 1-hexene for both catalysts, which seem to be related to the differences in chemical reactivity amongst substrates, i.e., less electron-rich double bonds result in more difficult epoxidation, or steric/size limitations [1,14,19]. Except for cyclohexene and limonene, in which allylic oxidation occurred to some extent (alcohol and ketone production), all the other substrates were 100 % selective for epoxidation, for both catalysts. Overall, TONs (see Table 1) do not indicate clear superiority of one catalyst in relation to the other confirming that the observed reactivity is determined by the grafted active catalytic component which is common in both catalysts and it is the [MnII-L] complex. On the other hand, MnII -L-SS550ox seems to have a slight advantage in terms of TOFs (see Table 1, Fig. 7 ), which indicates faster kinetics by this catalyst. MnII -L-SS550ox reached the equilibrium at 1.5 h for cyclohexene and cyclooctene epoxidation, compared with 2 h for MnII -L-SW550ox for the same substrates (Fig. 8 ). The highest TOFs obtained corresponded to cyclohexene for both MnII -L-SS550ox (551 h−1) and MnII -L-SW550ox (455 h−1). As observed previously for other carbon materials [9,21], the highest graphitized character of MnII -L-SS550ox, as shown by our Raman data (Fig. 3), promotes the fast catalytic kinetics. Since the catalytic performance evaluation also includes the material’s stability and recyclability [4,8] both MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox were rewashed and reused in at least three runs (Fig. 9 ). Although there was a gradual loss of cyclohexene conversion efficiency, MnII -L-SW550ox exhibited total conversion of up to 1981 TONs till the third reuse (1036 TONs for epoxides), being the more resistant catalyst, versus 1284 TONs (838 TONs for epoxides) for MnII -L-SS550ox . To better understand the stability differences observed, the recovered catalysts, i.e. after three-fold washing with MeOH, as well as the filtrates after the second (MnII -L-SS550ox ) and third (MnII -L-SW550ox ) re-uses were analyzed by EPR (Figs. 10 and 11 ). The filtrate from the sample containing MnII -L-SS550ox was analyzed after the second use because this catalyst lost most of its efficiency in this run (epoxide yield dropped to 62 %). It is obvious that for MnII -L-SS550ox , much of the metal complex loss occurred during the first catalytic use when comparing the EPR spectra of the catalysts before and after their use in the catalytic reaction. On the other hand, MnII -L-SW550ox maintained higher conversion rates in the second cycle, losing efficiency slower (Fig. 10). Only after three uses did MnII -L-SW550ox lose most of the attached metal complex. The EPR spectra of the active catalyst show that MnII is coordinated with the ligand L, though the spectra of the filtrate indicate that –compared to the MnII-L spectra– MnII is no longer coordinated to L [19]. Insights aspects Biochar-based hybrid materials have been synthesized by a covalent grafting process to produce {MnII-L@BC} catalysts. The metal complex grafting efficiency i.e. as quantified by the loading shows that the structural profile of the carbon matrix plays a key role. The two biochars differ in their composition regarding the graphitized sp2 domains and alkyl/carboxyl sp3 units. SW550ox with a more compacted structure containing sp3 units more robustly bound in the biochar matrix was able to bind 0.21 mmol g−1 of catalytic MnII-L complexes. The material SS550ox retained lower concentration of carboxyl–units thus was able to bind 0.14 mmol g−1 of catalytic MnII-L complexes, which is ∼60% of SW550ox . This reveals that biochars possess an inherent variability in their composition and in terms of types of carbon units, and this is reflected in the hybrid materials obtained after functionalization. However, diligent control of the grafted units concentration and type allows the engineering of catalytic hybrids able to perform efficiently epoxidation of alkenes at high TONs and TOFs. A key finding of the present work is that there is an anti-correlation between the catalytic kinetics i.e. TOFs, and the reusability of the catalyst, i.e. its resilience to degradation under oxidative turnovers. Thus, the catalyst MnII -L-SS550ox , which exhibited higher TOFs, was less stable than the MnII -L-SW550ox catalyst, which showed lower TOFs. Simaioforidou et al. [21] obtained similar results, demonstrating that catalysts with faster kinetics suffer faster oxidative destruction, offsetting the advantages (speed versus stability). Efficiency loss occurred due to the destabilization of the catalytic centers in this highly oxidative medium (up to 350 mV), which resulted in leaching and loss of the metal complex from the supporting biochars. Nonetheless, both MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox exhibited activity for at least two and three consecutive reuses respectively, demonstrating their potential as profitable catalysts. Cyclohexene epoxidation occurred concomitantly with the consumption of H2O2, which caused the redox potential decrease in solution. Mavrogiorgou et al. [7] have already explained the mechanistic efficiency of the same MnII Schiff-base complex grafted on the biochars used in the present study. As shown in detail previously [7], ammonium acetate used herein as a necessary co-catalyst [7,21], accelerates the evolution of MnII centers to MnIV in the presence of H2O2, promoting its coordination to the metal and generating the intermediate MnII−OOH. After the heterolytic cleavage of the OO bond, there is the generation of the electrophilic species MnIV꞊O. Due to the π bond found in olefins (nucleophilic sites), this active species transfers its oxygen atom to the substrate, catalyzing the epoxidation reaction. The efficiencies of the present biochar-based MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox hybrid materials are comparable to the best TONs achieved so far for epoxidation performances by metal catalysts immobilized on carbonaceous matrices (activated carbon, pyrolytic carbon, and carbon nanomaterials) [7,9,11,21]. On the other hand, the reactions with our biochars were faster (1.5 and 2 h) than when activated carbon (5 h) [7,21] was used as support. Of pertinence is that MnII -L-SS550ox and MnII -L-SW550ox yielded higher TOFs in comparison to homologous catalysts grafted on silica-based supports [2,7,11] confirming that the carbonaceous supports, even those which derived from agro-wastes, generate kinetically very fast epoxidation catalysts. This can be attributed to the hydrophobic character of the biochar support, which directly favors the reaction, and has been extensively documented by our group [7,11]. It is also worth to highlight that our reactions take very small amounts of catalyst, in a low catalyst-to-substrate ratio (1:1000 μmols), and effectively run with a green and easily decomposable oxidant (H2O2). This condition and the fact that the two biochars from agro-residues evaluated here are wastes, make the use of biochar as a support matrix for catalysis technologies very favorable, demonstrating its high potential for the fine-chemistry economy. Conclusions Two biochars from agro-residues were used as supporting material for the synthesis of hybrid catalytic materials [MnII-L@BC] via covalent grafting of a Mn catalyst. A detailed physicochemical and catalytic olefin epoxidation study has been performed; using in-situ Raman and EPR spectroscopies, we have studied the molecular evolution of the carbon matrix and the Mn catalyst during the oxidative catalytic process. The two biochars differ in their composition regarding the graphitized sp2 domains and alkyl/carboxyl sp3 units. The highest graphitized character of MnII -L-SS550ox promotes the fast catalytic kinetics. A key finding of the present work is that there is an anti-correlation between the catalytic kinetics and the reusability of the catalyst, offsetting the advantages (speed versus stability). This study demonstrated that the [MnII-L@BC] catalysts outperform the corresponding SiO2-based hybrid catalysts [2,7,11] when comparing their kinetic profile, confirming that the carbonaceous supports, even those which derived from agro-wastes, generate kinetically very fast epoxidation catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A novel type of hybrid catalytic materials [MnII-L@BC] has been developed using biochar (BC) as support material for covalent grafting of a MnII Schiff-base catalyst (MnII-L). The hybrid [MnII-L@BC] materials have been evaluated for an important catalytic process, epoxidation of olefins using H2O2 as oxidant. A number of different substrates were used, with cyclohexene achieving the highest yields. When compared to the non-grafted, homogeneous MnII-L, the hybrid catalysts [MnII-L@BC] show a significant enhancement of the catalytic efficiency i.e. as documented by the increase of Turnover Numbers (TONs) (826 for [MnII -L-SS550ox ] and 822 for [MnII -L-SW550ox ]) and Turnover Frequencies (TOFs) (551 h−1 for [MnII -L-SS550ox ] and 411 h−1 for [MnII -L-SW550ox ]). The interfacial catalytic mechanism and the role of the BC support have been analyzed by Raman and Electron Paramagnetic Resonance spectroscopies. Based on these data we discuss a mechanism where the high efficiency of the hybrid materials involves the biochar carbon layers acting as promoters of the substrate and products kinetics. To a broader context, this work exemplifies that biochar-based hybrid materials are potent for oxidative catalysis technologies.
coredata.dc:title: Biochar as supporting material for heterogeneous Mn(II) catalysts: Efficient olefins epoxidation with H2O2
